title: Groundwater Modeling with Machine Learning Techniques: Ljubljana Polje Aquifer

author: Klemen Kenda, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: In the First 2 presentations, we have heard a little bit about motor for Cities project and in the second presentation we have heard about all the infrastructure that makes this data that we have in the project available.
So the work that we are presenting here, which is data driven modeling, sort of builds on these achievements.
So the outline of my presentation will be like this in the beginning, call present our use case.

And what's our motivation to do this work then I will do again a brief introduction into machine learning and data driven techniques just for those of you who haven't been presented previous presentations.
And then I will show you how actually this data driven.
Methodology works in practice, So what is?
What are the challenges?
What can go wrong and how we have achieved approximately good results in the end, which I will present in the very end of this presentation.
So in new Ghana we have in the Libyan region, we have around 60 sensors or we had a Brown 60 sensors through history that we measure measuring groundwater level at the present time.

12 of these sensors are measuring this data, so according to the my colleagues, which are civil engineers and work a lot with the water, they say that groundwater levels are the principal source of information about the hydrologic stress in the environment.
So this by itself is a good motivation to.
Work on this topic and another long term goal that we have is to somehow show how groundwater is interconnected with the urban planning.
So this is some kind of the Holy Grail for us which we don't want.
We don't know if we will be able to achieve for our branch.
So for the data science it would be also really nice achievement if we could show that data driven models which don't know anything about the hydrology and any physical phenomena in the groundwater.
If we could with this agnostic model, somehow show that we can get good or comperable results to the models that are used nowadays in this domain.
So the data mining process itself is pretty standard, so this is the study that has been performed on the thousands of companies that are dealing with data mining out there.

So basically we start up here in this cycle we need to understand from our domain what we what approximately what we want to achieve, and then we need to look at our data and understand whether this can be achieved within our data.
This is a process which constantly goes on an once we are satisfied with our.
With our problem definition, then we go to the data preparation, which is here.
So data preparation is really tedious job.
It takes approximately 80% of all the time of a data scientist.
So basically we are just crunching this number and putting them together and making them usable for our models.
So this is this face.
Once the data is ready, we put it in the models and then we also test these models based on the results.
We check whether these models are satisfactory.
If not, we go.
We repeat the cycle again, otherwise we deploy them in practice, OK, and so the crucial part in here is this modeling and this modeling in our case is achieved with.

The data driven techniques, which are all under the umbrella of machine learning when in this work we will present you how we estimated groundwater levels in groundwater levels, which is a continuous value measured usually in the meters above sea level.
We have used the supervised learning process, which means that we know what we are trying to predict and we use.
Of course the regression problems.
The methods that we have used are these linear regression decision trees, random forests.
And gradient boosting.
So some of these methods are pretty simple.

Those are the first tool, but usually in the cases of environmental modeling, random forest and gradient boosting really are very compatible to the state of the art or even in some cases they are the state of the art.
If anybody will be interested, maybe in the end of the presentation I could tell you a few words about why gradient boosting is so effective.
But there are other things.
That we can do so nowadays.
Very popular method is deep learning.
Deep learning is application of very large neural networks to this data mining problems and usually it has been shown that these techniques make very good results.
OK, in supervised learning we usually start with a bunch of data.
In our case this will be groundwater levels, data and weather data becausw.
In our model we will try to show that just knowing the weather we can tell you a lot about what will happen with groundwater levels.
OK then we need to clean this data and fuse it together and our goal is to get very nicely ordered data in the forms of these feature vectors.
These feature vectors are built like this.
In our case this will be the weather data, the first part.
Becausw this will be the attributes with which we will try to estimate the groundwater level and this will be the so-called label.
This will be the actual groundwater level and this will be the thing that we want to predict.
So this is the basic idea of supervised learning.
Once we have this data ready, we put it into the learning process and the result is the model.
Once again I want to stress and this is not enough.
Maybe in this community these models are agnostic to whatever is happening behind.
They only learn from the data.
So if you want our groundwater modeling to represent some knowledge that we have in this domain, we need to put it inside within the data, not with the model and how this works.

So when we then see a bunch of unseen data, another feature vector, an other data for the weather for tomorrow in two days in three days, we put it into the model and our prediction will tell us what the groundwater level will be OK, so this all seems fine.
And let's see our definition one, but once again.
So for input data we use weather data from Ljubljana, region, temperatures, precipitation, snow data, sun duration and cloud cover.
What we want to predict our groundwater levels.
So I have presented all this methodology, it's superb.
This is the data and here are the result.
OK, so the blue line represents groundwater level and the orange line represents our prediction.
So basically I hope you will see that this is very far from good, so we used here linear regression and OK.
Linear regression is a simple method.
So why don't we use something more complex?
Light support vector machines.
The result is like this.
OK maybe maybe those two didn't workout.
So we tried decision trees again, same thing.
Random Forest, which is usually the state of the art in this area.
Again, bad results.
So what went wrong?
The idea usually in data mining, is that it's not so important which methods you use at least.
Not so much.
It's more important what data you put in.
So what knowledge do you acquire from the data?
And this is what we did.
Oh well, in the sorry.
Another thing we did for so we were trying to predict groundwater levels.
The absolute value of groundwater levels this, and only with the weather data from a particular day.
This of course doesn't make sense, so maybe we thought that before doing anything else we would change.
Our labels and not particular water level, but daily changes of groundwater, so this is something that we can describe better with the weather.
OK and here are there.

Salt, maybe it's not so obvious, but you can see that this orange line now followed the measurement data a little bit better, but still, the R2 R-squared measures were pretty bad around 0.2, so we need it to do also something.
With the features.
So in the beginning, as you have seen before, we have used approximately 8 different data streams from the weather data.
What we did and this thing is called so called feature engineering.
We sort of expanded those features data and to expand it into more than 500 different features.
What we did we thought we thought like this.
So when there is some precipitation in the area probably and we're not water experts probably take sometimes before this water gets into the ground.
So we introduce different time shifts here for all the features that we have and those time shift or from one day to 100 days.
We just checked everything and also we thought like if there is some precipitation in Monday and then it is Sunny, maybe this doesn't have so much effect or in the.

In the contrary to the case when we have a lot of rain each day, so we also took averages averages for one day for one week, one month, up to 100 days again, and we have built all these features that we have here.
500 features out of those, we chose those that are best coral.
Hate it with our groundwater change so the blue line represents groundwater change and here are some features.
So one very good feature was precipitation average for six days.
That one correlates pretty good with groundwater change and also this was a bit surprisingly.
Cloud cover average for the last nine days.
So probably this cloud cover has something to do with the weather in the larger area of Ljubljana region.
Again, we have had here like 500 different.
Correlations, and when checking which one to use, we use this matrix.
This matrix is called the correlation matrix on both axis.
It represents the features, the features themselves, but we need to read this table just graphically in colors.
So each line in this table represents a characteristic of a particular feature.
So in this.
Matrix we see that.
These two blocks, this block and this block are pretty similar to one another.
I hope you can all see this.
This means that basically these features look alike one another.

There are some minor changes and when we have to choose about so, our idea for the model is that we take into the model as many unrelated features as possible, and both need to be strongly correlated to the thing that we are predicting.
So basically what we did, we took the best features.
Then we took one.
For example, it was from this line.
Then we check the other.
It was from this line.
We took it again and then we check the 3rd and it was again from this line and we said OK.
This feature maybe does not bring so much new information and we discarded it and so on.
And we took something about 20 features from our modeling, OK?
And So what changed again?
So we were predicting groundwater level changes and we use these shifted features and here.
The results OK.
Here you can see that basically all the models fit much better to the data and especially I think this last one, which is our best results is pretty good.
We were satisfied with this, but this doesn't tell us much.
We transform this.
Back into the space of groundwater levels in meter above sea level.
So maybe at the first glance these two charts show some errors, but we need to look in.
This chart is not the how.

Absolutely these things fit together, but if the shapes of these lines, if they approximately correlate, so this is important, so can we catch the dynamics of groundwater level change so cause in practice?
We know that weather prediction can be done to reliably to up to three days or maybe 10 days ahead, and we will never move more than 10 days ahead in this measurement.
So these changes absolute changes will be really small.
This is by the way, almost two years of data in here, so we were very satisfied with these results.
And here are some measures.
So with gradient boosting we came to our square measure of 0.64, which is not really good, but you need to take into account that only weather data was used for this.
So very little information has been chosen.
To do this so.
How to improve the model?
Usually we do this with additional feature engineering we should take maybe weather data from the wider area.
We should check what is going up on up the stream of the rivers that come to Ljubljana.
Maybe we could even use surface water measurements like for the rivers and so on.
We could try building different derivatives so maybe not in this case it is not so important but in some other main cities usually use.
Cool to take.

I don't know some feature like groundwater level and if this feature is represented in quadratic form or cubic form or square root form somewhere you do this transformation and then you check it whether this correlates or and if it gives any new information to your model then there are land use anthropogenic features and so on.
Another thing that we need to do is to better define our use cases.
So now we have a general algorithm that just based on the weather can predict what will happen in groundwater.

If we have a case like we want to know what will happen with groundwater in three days time, then we can apply this and once we apply this we can also use groundwater level itself as a feature from 3 days ago.
Why is this important?

One thing that we have found in our models is that at some point our models always failed and then we checked what happened and we found out that there was a severe draft in Ljubljana between 2011 and 2012 and what happened there is that water levels didn't go below some certain threshold.
And our models learning from the weather there and they learned no change, so they failed.
In all other cases.
So and this is something new that we have found in this aquifer and it can be explored by the by the experts.
So then there are of course other methods deep learning of course is something to go.
And another thing is generalization of the models.
So these data driven models, they are only valid for one data point.
So where are we measuring groundwater only there they will be successful.
We cannot generalize them to other.
Other sensors we can do that with introducing some metadata like location, distance from River, I don't know geologic properties and so on.
OK, and there are some other directions.
So in water management like Mattina said before, we are expected to have new technology that would bring a lot of data in and we need to be able to process this data in a big data manner.
So stream mining is one of the approaches to take there and we are working for that.
On that we want also to implement a real time platform matejka shown that some of the work is already in place.
We need to build on top of it and then there are these two.
These two bullets, so once we have a model ready, why don't we look at the model itself?
What does it tell us?
How do these features correlate?
What does this model predict that influenced the groundwater?
The experts should check this and see if there is something new new insight.
And of course what I said before is to compare these results with the process based models and see whether there is some improvement on the state of the art there.
OK, so this is it.
Thank you.
